Ontologies

There are two series of ontologies: more generic and project ontologies.

The generic ontologies comprise the core concepts for scholarly editions, as well as the bulk of entities modeled in agreement with the edition projects.

The project ontologies contain entities linked to the specific subjects of edition projects, but they are still usable outside the respective projects.

Generic Ontologies

Agent

Formal description of an agent, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Calendar

Formal description of calendar, subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Catholic Orders

Formal description of catholic orders, general subclasses, related classes, properties, and instances.

Catholic Organization

Formal description of catholic organization, general subclasses, related classes, properties, and instances.

Concept

Formal description of concept, its general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Creating

Formal description of creating by humans, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Device

Formal description of a device, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Document

Formal description of document, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Event

Formal description of event, general subclasses such as action, related classes and properties.

Human Geography

Formal description of human geography, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Human

Formal description of a human, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Image

Formal description of image as a visual resource in the broadest sense, its general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Indology

Formal description of Indology, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Information Carrier

Formal description of information carrier in broadest sense, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Language

Formal description of language, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Languages

Formal description of human natural languages, referring to the ISO 639 standards.

Letter Corresponding

Formal description of letter corresponding, related classes, and properties.

Linguistic Morphology

Formal description of linguistic-morphology, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Linguistics

Formal description of linguistics, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Literature

Formal description of literature, its general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Logic

Formal description of logic, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Mathematics

Formal description of general concepts in mathematics.

Note Structure

Formal description of note structure, subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Organization

Formal description of organization involving persons, general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Philosophies

Formal description of philosophies, general subclasses, related classes, properties, and instances.

Philosophy

Formal description of philosophy, general subclasses, related classes, properties, and instances.

Physical Entity

Formal description of physical entity in broadest sense, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Physical Geography

Formal description of physical geography, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Prosodic Structure

Formal description of prosodic structure, subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Publishing

Formal description of publishing, its general subclasses, related classes and properties.

Scholarly Editing

Formal description of scientific editing, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Scholasticism

Formal description of elements in Scholasticism.

Standoff Annotation

Formal description of standoff-annotation in broadest sense, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Teaching

Formal description of teaching, general subclasses such as action, related classes and properties.

Terminology Code Systems

Formal description of terminology and code systems and their datatypes, as link between system data and OWL-ontologies and RDF-data.

Text Editing

Formal description of text editing, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Text Expression

Formal description of text expression, based on FRBROO, in broadest sense, with general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Text Structure

Formal description of text structure, subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Text

Formal description of text in broadest sense, general subclasses, related classes, and properties.

Time

Formal description of time relations.

Project Ontologies

Atharvaveda

Formal description of specific concepts in the scientific study of Atharvaveda.

Jacques Delille Poetry

Formal description of specific concepts in the scientific edition about citations of the poem 'L'Homme des champs' of Jacques Delille, 22 June 1738 – 1 May 1813.

Joseph Dietrich Monastery Diary

Formal description of specific concepts in the scientific study "Das Kloster-Tagebuch des Einsiedler Paters Joseph Dietrich, 1670-1704".

Petrus Lombardus Sentences

Formal description of specific concepts in the scientific study of Commentaries on Peter Lombard's Sentences, as in the Digital Repertory of Commentaries on Peter Lombard’s Sentences (DRCS).

Kuno Raeber Lyric

Formal description of elements in the online publication of the lyric work of the Swiss poet Kuno Raeber.

Johann Caspar Lavater Correspondence

Formal description of specific concepts in the critical edition of correspondence of Johann Caspar Lavater, 15 November 1741 - 2 January 1801.

Conrad Ferdinand Meyer Correspondence

Formal description of specific concepts in the critical edition of the correspondence of Conrad Ferdinand Meyer, 11 October 1825 – 28 November 1898.

Wolfram von Eschenbach Parzival

Formal description of specific concepts in the critical and digital edition of Wolfram von Eschenbach's 'Parzival'.
